area_name: Turtle Rock: A Crag for Kids

content.description:
Start as with

Donovan's Dihedral

, but veer left after clipping the bolt into a shallow, water groove. Follow the water groove to its top.

There is a route that seems to be between

Fiona's Route

and

Heads or Tails?

and doesn't match a description submitted to date.

There are 2 starts to this.  The right start is probably the wiser one to do.  Clamber aboard the rock to the right of a right-facing dihedral with 2 obvious pins.  The left start involves a double sidepull move, a right foot cam, and a left foot on a slanting groove.  Watch the abductor move or you may scrape up your left shin.  Move left into the dihedral.  This will be tougher for the very short.  Go upwards and join one of the other crowded lines above on the slab.

There is a bolt next to a #2 Camalot crack for an anchor.
content.protection: 2 pins, a bolt, a few small cams, and an anchor bolt & #2 Camalot for the anchor.
content.location:
This is left of the obvious, shallow crack for

Fiona's Route

by perhaps 10 feet.

content.description:
This is the furthest route left on the crag and is approached via the gully on the left side of the whole crag.

The next line up from

Cold North Shell

.

This has an alpine, untouched quality of blocks and cracks to the top of the slab.  It is best climbed on a cold day with gloves as a winter primer. Get your young alpinistas started early.

Take the overhang directly in the center of the crag and struggle over it to gain the small crack that splits slab above.

Perhaps this is best climbed with a top rope.
content.protection:
Trad rack. Use the anchor at top of

Fiona's Route

.

content.description:
Just left of

Heads or Tails?

is another overhanging start to gain the slab.  Power over the stout lip via the jug at the lip and other hidden holds.

Perhaps this is best done as a top rope.

This was the first route done on the crag and remains a favorite way to introduce newcomers to Turtle Rock.

Start in the short, steep, little, left-facing dihedral that sits 12 feet directly below a small tree. Climb a 5.7 shallow crack up to the tree and sling it for pro. Tip toe up and LEFT, out the slab to a bolt. Trend left into a crack and climb it to its top. Continue up until you reach 1 bolt anchor next to a nice crack for a hex.  Belay.

Continue up the mountaineering second pitch or carefully walk off to the RIGHT/south and down to the base.
content.protection: Rack of tricams, rack of wires, 1 bolt, and a 1 anchor bolt at the top belay.

content.description:
This is the dihedral on the far RIGHT side of Turtle Rock and makes for a great first short lead climb for kids.

Start in a right-facing dihedral, then step left into a crack.

Climb up to the bolt. Stay right and traverse around right side of the bulge.

Find the good crack for belay anchors.
content.location:
It is on the far right side of the crag.

Find a tree growing from the rock only 6 feet from the ground. The start begins about 6 feet RIGHT of

Fiona's Route

.

content.description:
Climb the big, zig zag, roof crack and fight your way with hands and fists to gain the slab above.

Follow any route to the top.
content.protection: Currently a fixed nut protects the overhang...but bring additional cams.  There is 1 bolt on left side of slab.
content.location: The biggest roof crack in the series...with a fixed wired nut in the center of it.

content.description:
Left into the gully, find the cold, north-facing wall of Turtle Rock. Piece together a nice little wall of flakes, cracks, and edges to join the left side of the main slab above.

This is a good introduction to alpine like rock conditions and for a first winter outing. It can be climbed in gloves.

Start in the same dihedral as for

Fiona's Route

. Climb up to the tree, sling it as pro and continue RIGHT up the flake/crack to the 1 bolt shared by

Donovan's Dihedral

& Water Groove. Now veer back LEFT taking a crack through the bulge. Find a ledge to belay.
This micro-adventure avoids the big overhangs but snakes up nicely to the slab on the left hand arete.
content.protection: A rack of wired nuts, 1 bolt.
content.location:
This is located on the left side of the crag, just left of the big roof crack of

Cracked Shell

.

pathTokens: Turtle Rock: A Crag for Kids
